interestingFact: There are 195 countries in the world today, including 193 United Nations member states and 2 observer states.
Afghanistan is home to the Hindu Kush mountain range, with peaks over 7,000 meters.
Albania has over 750,000 bunkers built during the communist era.
Algeria is the largest country in Africa by land area.
Andorra is a small landlocked country in the Pyrenees mountains between France and Spain.
Angola is known for its rich biodiversity and is home to the rare giant sable antelope.
Antigua and Barbuda has 365 beaches, one for each day of the year.
Argentina is home to the highest peak in the Americas, Aconcagua, standing at 6,960 meters.
Armenia was the first country to adopt Christianity as its state religion in 301 AD.
Australia is home to the Great Barrier Reef, the largest coral reef system in the world.
Austria is known for its musical heritage, being the birthplace of composers like Mozart and Strauss.
Azerbaijan is home to the ancient city of Baku, with its medieval walled inner city.
The Bahamas is known for its pink sand beaches, particularly on Harbour Island.
Bahrain is an archipelago of 33 islands in the Persian Gulf.
Bangladesh has the largest mangrove forest in the world, the Sundarbans, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Barbados is known as the birthplace of rum and has the oldest rum distillery in the world, Mount Gay Rum, established in 1703.
Belarus is home to the Belovezhskaya Pushcha National Park, one of the last and largest remaining parts of the immense primeval forest that once covered Europe.
Belgium is famous for its chocolate, producing over 220,000 tons annually.
Belize has the second-largest barrier reef in the world, the Belize Barrier Reef.
Benin is the birthplace of the Vodun (Voodoo) religion, which has influenced cultures worldwide.
Bhutan is the only country in the world to measure its success by Gross National Happiness instead of Gross Domestic Product.
Bolivia has the world's largest salt flat, Salar de Uyuni, which is over 10,000 square kilometers.
Bosnia and Herzegovina is home to the last remaining jungle in Europe, Perućica.
Botswana has the largest population of elephants in the world.
Brazil is home to the Amazon Rainforest, the largest tropical rainforest in the world.
Brunei has one of the highest standards of living in the world due to its oil and gas wealth.
Bulgaria is one of the oldest countries in Europe, founded in 681 AD.
Burkina Faso is known for its vibrant music scene and hosts the largest African film festival, FESPACO.
Burundi is one of the few countries in Africa whose borders were not determined by colonial rulers; they were based on the ancient Kingdom of Burundi.
Cabo Verde is an archipelago of 10 volcanic islands in the Atlantic Ocean.
Cambodia is home to Angkor Wat, the largest religious monument in the world.
Cameroon is often called 'Africa in miniature' because it features all major climates and vegetation of the continent.
Canada has the longest coastline of any country in the world, stretching over 202,080 kilometers.
The Central African Republic is home to the Dzanga-Sangha Special Reserve, which protects one of the most pristine rainforests in Africa.
Chad is home to the Zakouma National Park, which has seen a remarkable recovery in wildlife populations.
Chile is the longest north-south trending country in the world, stretching over 4,300 kilometers.
The Great Wall of China is visible from space on rare occasions.
Colombia is the only country in South America with coastlines on both the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean Sea.
Comoros is known for its diverse culture and history, influenced by African, Arab, and French elements.
The Democratic Republic of the Congo is home to the Congo River, the deepest river in the world.
The Republic of the Congo is home to the Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park, which protects a large area of pristine rainforest.
Costa Rica is a leader in environmental protection, with over 25% of its land protected as national parks or reserves.
Croatia has over 1,000 islands along its Adriatic coastline.
Cuba is home to nine UNESCO World Heritage Sites, including Old Havana and its fortifications.
Cyprus is the third largest island in the Mediterranean Sea.
The Czech Republic has the highest beer consumption per capita in the world.
Denmark is home to the oldest monarchy in the world, dating back to the 10th century.
Djibouti is strategically located at the entrance to the Red Sea and is home to one of the saltiest bodies of water in the world, Lake Assal.
Dominica is known as the 'Nature Island' due to its unspoiled natural beauty and diverse ecosystems.
The Dominican Republic is home to the highest peak in the Caribbean, Pico Duarte, standing at 3,098 meters.
East Timor is one of the youngest countries in the world, gaining independence in 2002.
Ecuador is home to the Galápagos Islands, famous for their unique wildlife and role in Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.
The Pyramids of Giza are one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
El Salvador is the smallest country in Central America but has the highest population density in the region.
Equatorial Guinea is the only Spanish-speaking country in Africa.
Eritrea has a diverse landscape, including the Dahlak Archipelago in the Red Sea.
Estonia is one of the most digitally advanced countries, with e-residency and online voting.
Eswatini is one of the last absolute monarchies in the world.
Ethiopia is the only African country never colonized by a European power.
Fiji is an archipelago of over 300 islands in the South Pacific.
Finland has over 188,000 lakes, the highest number in the world.
The Eiffel Tower in Paris was once the tallest man-made structure in the world.
Gabon has one of the highest percentages of forest cover in the world, with over 80% of its land covered by forests.
The Gambia is the smallest country on mainland Africa.
Georgia is one of the oldest wine-producing regions in the world, with evidence of wine production dating back 8,000 years.
Germany is home to the world's oldest brewery, Weihenstephan, founded in 1040.
Ghana was the first sub-Saharan African country to gain independence from colonial rule in 1957.
Greece is considered the birthplace of Western civilization and democracy.
Grenada is known as the 'Spice Isle' for its production of nutmeg and mace.
Guatemala is home to the ancient Mayan city of Tikal, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Guinea has the world's largest bauxite reserves, used in aluminum production.
Guinea-Bissau is known for its diverse wildlife, including rare species like the saltwater hippopotamus.
Guyana is home to Kaieteur Falls, one of the tallest single-drop waterfalls in the world.
Haiti was the first independent nation in Latin America and the Caribbean, gaining independence in 1804.
Honduras is home to the ancient Mayan city of Copán, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Hungary has one of the oldest metro systems in the world, with the Budapest Metro opening in 1896.
Iceland is home to more than 130 volcanoes, many of which are still active.
India is the birthplace of four major religions: Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, and Sikhism.
Indonesia is the largest archipelago in the world, with over 17,000 islands.
Iran is home to one of the world's oldest civilizations, dating back to 7000 BC.
Iraq is home to the ancient city of Babylon, one of the most famous cities of antiquity.
Ireland is known as the 'Emerald Isle' due to its lush green landscapes.
Israel has the highest number of museums per capita in the world.
Italy is home to the smallest country in the world, Vatican City.
Jamaica is the birthplace of reggae music, popularized by Bob Marley.
Japan has over 6,800 islands, with the four largest making up 97% of its land area.
Jordan is home to the ancient city of Petra, one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.
Kazakhstan is the largest landlocked country in the world.
Kenya is home to the Maasai Mara, one of the best places in the world to see wildlife.
Kiribati is the only country in the world to be situated in all four hemispheres.
Kuwait has the world's fifth-largest oil reserves.
Kyrgyzstan is home to the Tian Shan mountain range, which covers 80% of the country.
Laos is the most heavily bombed country per capita in history, due to the Vietnam War.
Latvia has one of the fastest internet speeds in the world.
Lebanon is home to the ancient city of Byblos, one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.
Lesotho is the only country in the world that lies entirely above 1,000 meters in elevation.
Liberia was founded by freed American slaves in 1847.
Libya has the largest proven oil reserves in Africa.
Liechtenstein is one of the smallest countries in the world and has no airport.
Lithuania was the first Soviet republic to declare independence in 1990.
Luxembourg has the highest GDP per capita in the world.
Madagascar is home to unique wildlife, including lemurs, found nowhere else on Earth.
Malawi is known as the 'Warm Heart of Africa' due to its friendly people.
Malaysia is home to the Petronas Towers, which were the tallest buildings in the world from 1998 to 2004.
The Maldives is the lowest country in the world, with an average elevation of 1.5 meters above sea level.
Mali is home to the ancient city of Timbuktu, a center of learning and trade in the Middle Ages.
Malta has three UNESCO World Heritage Sites, including the Megalithic Temples, which are among the oldest free-standing structures in the world.
The Marshall Islands is one of the most remote countries in the world, located in the Pacific Ocean.
Mauritania is home to the Richat Structure, also known as the 'Eye of the Sahara,' a prominent circular feature visible from space.
Mauritius was the only known habitat of the dodo bird, which became extinct in the 17th century.
Mexico is home to the world's smallest volcano, Cuexcomate, which is only 13 meters tall.
Micronesia is made up of over 600 islands spread across the western Pacific Ocean.
Moldova has the largest wine cellar in the world, Mileștii Mici, which stretches for 200 kilometers.
Monaco is the second smallest country in the world and has the highest population density.
Mongolia is the least densely populated country in the world.
Montenegro is home to the Tara River Canyon, the deepest canyon in Europe.
Morocco is home to the ancient city of Marrakech, known for its vibrant markets and historic sites.
Mozambique has the only national flag in the world that features a modern weapon, an AK-47.
Myanmar is home to the Shwedagon Pagoda, one of the most sacred Buddhist sites in the world.
Namibia is home to the Namib Desert, one of the oldest deserts in the world.
